section.name: Introduction
section.p: jidgen has a variety of command line options to configure and modify its behavior.

A very good starting point is the following example.
It uses two variables f and l to reference the externally specified first and last name of a user.
The template string utilizes the given data through their variable names as substrings and also adds a counter element.
java -jar jidgen.jar -Tf John -Tl Doe -T 2f:2l:N4++
Generated output: jodo0000
This is a copy-and-paste example for a quick understanding of jidgen . For a detailed list of jidgen's options see below .

tr.td: Template string that describes the composition of the generated id(s).
Data to associate with the chosen lower case letter variable [a-z] for later use in the template definition.
The number of id proposals to return.
Enable the passwd filter with the default passwd file (Default: /etc/passwd).
Sets an alternate passwd file location for the passwd filter.
Enable the blacklist filter with the default blacklist file (Default: blacklist).
Sets an alternate file location for the blacklist filter.
Enable the shellcmd filter with the default command to run with each id. (Default: ./filter.sh %s).
The command to be executed for filtering ids. The id is inserted at %s. An exit code of 0 will filter the given id.
Set the terminal width for column output (Default: 80).
Displays a very verbose help page with more detailed explanations.
